body: Hidden is checked if you have configured your forward cashflow and cashflow transactions to be created as hidden in contract preferences.

title: Forward cashflow transactions
body: Counter, Counter portfolio, Market place, Settlement place, Description, Internal info,Tags

title: Forward cashflow transactions
body: Counter, Counter portfolio, Market place, Settlement place, Description, Internal info and Tags are filled in based on the information you filled in on the contract. This ensures the transactions generated based on your contracts are categorized consistently, allowing you for example to search and report them.

title: Forward cashflow positions
body: When you save a contract, the system recalculates the portfolio's reporting data to show the forward cashflow positions for both legs of the contract, opened with the forward cashflow transactions. The forward cashflow positions are open from the start of the contract until the cashflowscashflows take effect at the end of the contract.

title: Forward cashflow positions
body: You'll get one positive and one negative forward cashflow position. The Market value of the forward cashflow position tells you the discounted present value of the forward cashflow on the selected date. The system calculates the discounted present value of each forward cashflow with the yield curves defined in the system (see Preference - Yield curves).

title: Forward cashflow positions
body: Forward cashflows are valuated automatically during nightly report update based on latest yield curve prices. In addition, you can manually revaluate your forward cashflow securities in the Market data info tab in the -security window or Top menu.

title: Add trade orders
body: You can create trade orders from scratch or based on a portfolio position, for example, to sell or buy a security already in your portfolio. You can also create trade orders based on a position in multiple portfolios for partial redemptions or security switches.

title: Add trade orders
body: Adding a trade order in a portfolio doesn't affect portfolio positions. Portfolio positions and cash amounts are recalculated when a transaction is accepted.

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: To create a trade order from scratch, do the following:

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: In the Overview, select the portfolio in which you want to add a trade order. If you select the portfolio first, the trade order is directly linked to the correct portfolio.

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: Click New trade order in the New menu (top left) and select a security type.

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: Fill in the fields in the Trade order window. For descriptions of the fields, see Trade order window in FA Back reference.

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: Save the trade order.

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: To create a new trade order based on the position in the selected portfolio, do the following:

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: In the Overview, right-click the position row and select New.

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: Select Trade order with position's security and amount.

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: Fill in the fields. For descriptions of the fields, see Trade order window in FA Back reference.

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: Save the trade order.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: You can create trade orders based on a position in multiple portfolios, for example, to do partial redemptions or switches from one security to another using the reinvest option.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: To create trade orders based on the position in multiple portfolios, do the following:

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: In the Positions view, search for a position to use as a starting point.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Click Create transactions and fill in the fields in the Generate transactions from positions window:

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Create: The type of object to create. Select "Trade orders".

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Transaction type: The transaction type to use. The list of available types depends on the selected security.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Execution method: The trade order execution method.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Amount: The amount as percentage of the original position size.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Unit price: The unit price to use in the trade orders. Enter a question mark to get the latest price available in the system.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Transaction date

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Settlement date

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Tags: The tags for the trade orders.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: If the selected transaction type has a positive cash effect, reinvest by clicking Add security and filling in the fields, including the security to reinvest in. You can reinvest into multiple securities.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Click Preview trade orders to check the trade orders to be created. You can uncheck trade orders you don't want the system to create.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Click Confirm.

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Limit definitions are the investment constraints you want to follow. They include the values to follow and thresholds for warnings and breaches. You can set up limit definitions in FA Back or import them into the system (see File format for importing limit definitions in FA Back reference). You can also export limit definitions as CSV files (see Export limit definition groups).

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Limit definitions are organized into groups. For example, you can group individual limit definitions that set proportions of different security types in a portfolio. Grouping lets you link multiple limit definitions to a portfolio at once and facilitates their monitoring. In addition, groups are useful in automatic analysis, scheduling and monitoring of limits: you can schedule to analyze different groups at different intervals and set up different kinds of monitoring for different limit groups.

title: Set up limit definitions
body: You can set up limit definitions in Preference → Portfolios → Limit definitions:

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Create a limit group: Click Add group and enter a unique code and a name you want to see in the portfolio limits. A limit group is a "container" for individual limit definitions that allows you to manage similar limits together. Examples of limit groups: "UCITS limits", "Allocation limits" or similar.

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Create individual limit definitions in your limit group: Click Add a new limit definition and fill in the fields.

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Code

title: Set up limit definitions
body: A unique code for your limit definition.

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Name

title: Set up limit definitions
body: A descriptive name for your limit definition. The name is used to search for the limit, link the limit to your portfolio, and show the result of the limit. Names should indicate what the limit checks, for example: "Stock position's share less than 11%" or "Total market value of Finnish stocks less than 10 000 €".

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Choose the limit type and follow the instructions by the link depending on your choice.

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Analytics - build your limit based on values from Analytics+, for example, market value. See Limit definitions based on Analytics

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Profile - build your limit to analyze values you store in custom fields on your portfolio. See Limit definitions based on custom profile fields.

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Investment plan - build your limit to analyze your portfolio against its investment plan . See Limit definitions based on strategy, investment plan or model portfolio

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Model portfolio - build your limit to analyze your portfolio against its model portfolio . See Limit definitions based on strategy, investment plan or model portfolio

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Strategy - build your limit to analyze your portfolio against its strategy. See Limit definitions based on strategy, investment plan or model portfolio

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Set the limit thresholds.

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Minimum breach threshold

title: Set up limit definitions
body: If your limit value drops below this value, your limit will be breached.

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Minimum warning threshold

title: Set up limit definitions
body: If your limit value drops below this value, your limit will induce a warning.

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Maximum warning threshold

title: Set up limit definitions
body: If your limit exceeds this value, your limit will induce a warning.

title: Set up limit definitions
body: Maximum breach threshold

title: Set up limit definitions
body: If your limit exceeds this value, your limit will be breached.

title: Set up limit definitions
body: In case of absolute values in analytics-based limits and profile values, define the thresholds with a numeric value in the same unit as your limit definition fetches.

title: Set up limit definitions
body: In case of relative values in analytics-based limits, define the threshold with a numeric value between 0 and 1 - relative values are always analyzed as percentages, which are defined as a decimal number (e.g. 10% threshold defined as 0.1).

title: Set up limit definitions
body: In case of values from portfolio's strategy, investment plan or model portfolio, define the thresholds with a numeric value between 0 and 100 - these values are always analyzed as percentage, which are defined as an integer (e.g. 10% threshold defined as 10).

title: Set up limit definitions
body: After you set up a limit definition, you can link it to a portfolio (see Link limit definitions to portfolios) and analyze the limits pre-trade or post-trade.

title: Export limit definition groups
body: You can export limit definition groups and the limits within them in a CSV file.

title: Export limit definition groups
body: To export limit definition groups, do the following:

title: Export limit definition groups
body: Open Preference → Portfolios → Limit definitions.

title: Export limit definition groups
body: To export all limit groups, click Export and select "All groups". To export a single limit group, select the group, click Export, and choose "Selected group".

title: Export limit definition groups
body: The CSV containing the limit definition group is downloaded to your computer. You can, for example, edit the limit definitions and import them back into the FA system (see File format for importing limit definitions in FA Back reference).

title: Rebalance methods
body: FA platform lets you set multiple rebalancing parameters to control how the rebalancing logic calculates what to buy and sell. You can combine the parameters in various ways. Below are the most common rebalance methods, with the parameters to use for each of them.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: With conservative rebalancing, you can purchase securities using only the cash in the portfolio account. You can realign the portfolio with the model in two rounds. In the first round, the system sells the excess positions above the target and buys with the available cash. After executing the sells and acquiring cash, the second round buys additional positions with the newly available cash to rebalance the portfolio fully.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect conservative rebalancing in the following way:

title: Conservative rebalance
body: Buy trade orders with negative cash effect reduce the available cash to reserve cash for buys.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you should buy something but you already have a buy trade order for that security, or if you should sell but already have a sell trade order for the security, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: Example: You would need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: To apply the conservative rebalance method, choose "Conservative (buy only with extra cash in portfolio)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Full rebalance
body: With full rebalancing, you can buy securities using both available cash and the cash expected from suggested sales. This method calculates buys based on the estimated cash you will have after executing suggested sales with the latest market prices. With full rebalance, you can realign your entire portfolio against the model in one go.

title: Full rebalance
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you settle your trades promptly, so you have sufficient cash available to complete your purchases. To mitigate the risk, you can set a limit on the cash from sells to use for buys during a full rebalance. For example, instead of counting sell values at 100%, you can count them at 90% or 95%. This conservative method ensures that even if prices drop between rebalancing and executing your sales, you'll likely still have enough cash to complete your buys. See Preference - Portfolios for details.

title: Full rebalance
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect full rebalancing in the following way:

title: Full rebalance
body: Buy trade orders with negative cash effect reduce the available cash to reserve cash for buys.

title: Full rebalance
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you should buy something but you already have a buy trade order for that security, or if you should sell but already have a sell trade order for the security, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Full rebalance
body: Example: You would need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Full rebalance
body: To apply this method, choose "Full (buy both with extra cash in portfolio and cash from sells)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders
body: With full rebalance including outstanding orders, you can purchase securities using available cash, expected cash from recommended sells, and cash from outstanding trade orders with a positive cash effect (all statuses except "Open"), such as deposits and sells. Full rebalancing estimates available cash that will be received after executing all sells with the latest market prices. This method requires careful trade order management to ensure sufficient cash is available to complete your buys.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders
body: Before rebalancing, the system calculates expected positions. It sells any expected excess positions and buys with the cash expected to be available after executing these orders.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders
body: With full rebalance including outstanding trade orders, you can realign your entire portfolio at once, considering the effect of outstanding orders.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders
body: To apply this method, choose "Full including orders (also buy with cash from orders)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Exchange
body: With exchange, you can sell a portfolio position that is above the target and buy a position that is below the target with the cash you expect to get from selling. The cash received from sells is estimated based on the latest market prices, putting pressure on your trade order management to ensure you settle your sell so that you have enough cash available to execute your buy.

title: Exchange
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") are considered in the exchange.

title: Exchange
body: Buy trade orders with negative cash effect reduce the available cash to reserve cash for buys. (However, exchange will not use the your cash balance for the suggested trade orders).

title: Exchange
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you should buy something but you already have a buy trade order for that security, or if you should sell but already have a sell trade order for the security, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Exchange
body: Example: You would need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Exchange
body: You can swap one position for another without rebalancing your entire portfolio. This process sells positions above the target and uses the proceeds to buy positions below the target. The weights of the positions ensure the new position matches the investment weight of the old one.

title: Exchange
body: To apply this method:

title: Exchange
body: Choose "Exchange (buy only with cash from sells)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Exchange
body: Select the positions you want to exchange.

title: Invest cash
body: With the invest cash method, you can only use the excess cash in your account to buy securities, without making any other changes. It calculates purchases based on the available cash but does not involve selling any positions.

title: Invest cash
body: To apply this method:

title: Invest cash
body: Choose Restrict rebalancing to accounts in the Rebalance window. This ensures that rebalancing will only buy with the excess cash you have, but will not sell anything.

title: Invest cash
body: Choose "Conservative (buy both with extra cash in portfolio" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window.

title: Cover for cash
body: With the cover-for-cash method, you can only use sells to address a negative account balance without making any other changes to your portfolio. It calculates the necessary sells to reach your target cash level without generating additional sells or making any purchases. The rebalancing process only sells enough to cover the negative balance, preventing excess cash in the account, which this method aims to avoid.

title: Cover for cash
body: This method lets you sell a portion of your holdings to cover for a negative account balance, for example after withdrawing fees from the portfolio, without realigning the entire portfolio.

title: Cover for cash
body: To apply this method, choose Restrict rebalancing to accounts in the Rebalance window. This ensures that rebalancing will only sell to cover for the negative cash you have, but will not buy anything.

title: Model change
body: With the model change, you can update your portfolio model by selling the securities from the old model and investing everything into the securities in the new model.

title: Model change
body: You have an option to execute a model change either as Conservative rebalancing or Full rebalancing, depending on whether you prefer to do it gradually or all at once. Regardless of the method chosen, rebalancing will sell off your old positions entirely and reinvest the proceeds into the new positions.

title: Rebalance portfolios against a model portfolio
body: You can use model portfolios to keep the customers' investment portfolios in balance.

title: Step 1 - Link the investment portfolios to the model portfolios
body: To link the customer's investment portfolio to a model portfolio, do the following:

title: Step 1 - Link the investment portfolios to the model portfolios
body: Select the customer's portfolio and open the Portfolio window.

title: Step 1 - Link the investment portfolios to the model portfolios
body: Select the model portfolio in the Basic info tab, Model portfolio field.

title: Step 1 - Link the investment portfolios to the model portfolios
body: Click Save.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: To rebalance the investment portfolios against model portfolios and create trade orders:

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Depending on your business case, choose one of the options to rebalance investment portfolios:

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Rebalance a single portfolio. Select the investment portfolio on the Overview. Right-click it on the right and choose Rebalancing.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Rebalance all investment portfolios linked to a model portfolio. Use one of the options to open the Rebalance window:

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Click Rebalancing on the Rebalance view and select the model portfolio you want to use.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Click the Rebalancing button in the Model portfolio window for the model portfolio you want to use.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Choose the investment portfolios you want to rebalance in the table.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Rebalance selected portfolios against the model portfolios linked to them. Search the investment portfolios on the Portfolios view, click Rebalance at the bottom and select one of the options that include "Model portfolio" in the Rebalance against field.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Define rebalancing parameters for affected portfolios, the rebalancing logic, and trade order generation options. If needed, adjust the security shares in the model portfolios in the table. For more information about the fields, see Rebalance window. Once you defined all parameters, click Rebalance.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: View the trade orders suggested by the system. Use the filters at the top to adjust the list of trade orders. Once you are satisfied with the list, click Save.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Note that only visible trade orders are saved. To save all suggested trade orders, clear all filters before saving.

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: To execute the trade orders:

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: Search for the created trade orders in the Trade orders view and set their status to "Executable". Send the executable trade orders forward to buy and sell securities to the investment portfolios.

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: Once the trades are implemented in the market, execute trade orders in FA with the realized values to create transactions to the investment portfolios.

title: Related links
body: Model portfolio management in FA Back reference

title: Related links
body: File formats for importing model portfolios in FA Back reference

title: Rebalance portfolios against the investment plan
body: You can use an investment plan to keep your investment portfolios in balance. Follow the steps below to rebalance your investment portfolios against their investment plans.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: To rebalance investment portfolios against the investment plan and create trade orders:

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: Depending on your business case, choose one of the options to rebalance investment portfolios:

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: Rebalance a single portfolio. Select the investment portfolio on the Overview. Right-click it on the right and choose Rebalancing.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: Rebalance selected portfolios against the investment plans linked to them. Search the investment portfolios on the Portfolios view, click Rebalance at the bottom, and select one of the options that include "Investment plan" in the Rebalance against field.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: Define rebalancing parameters for affected portfolios, the rebalancing logic, and trade order generation options. If needed, adjust the security shares in the investment plans in the table. For more information about the fields, see Rebalance window. Once you defined all parameters, click Rebalance.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: View the trade orders suggested by the system. Use the filters at the top to adjust the list of trade orders. Once you are satisfied with the list, click Save.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: Note that only visible trade orders are saved. To save all suggested trade orders, clear all filters before saving.

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: To execute the trade orders:

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: Search for the created trade orders in the Trade orders view and set their status to "Executable". Send the executable trade orders forward to buy and sell securities to the investment portfolios.

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: Once the trades are implemented in the market, execute trade orders in FA with the realized values to create transactions to the investment portfolios.

title: Authority reporting
body: Authority reporting

title: Related links
body: Reporting in FA Back reference

title: Publish reports to documents
body: You can publish reports directly into the documents of contacts, portfolios, or trade orders. This allows you to generate reports and then instantly publish them to your clients, for example, within your external environment.

title: Publish reports to documents
body: You can publish reports to the documents of contacts, portfolios, or trade orders in the New report window:

title: Publish reports to documents
body: In the New report window, select the reports to generate and define the report parameters (see Report window in FA Back reference).

title: Publish reports to documents
body: Select one of following options as the Output type:

title: Publish reports to documents
body: Report per customer to documents

title: Publish reports to documents
body: Report per portfolio to documents

title: Publish reports to documents
body: Report per trade order to documents

title: Publish reports to documents
body: Fill in the additional fields for publishing the reports:

title: Publish reports to documents
body: Folder name

title: Publish reports to documents
body: When publishing reports to documents, the reports are also generated to a defined folder and can later be found in the Generated reports tab. The reports saved within the Generated reports tab are physically different files from the documents published in the documents of each customer, portfolio, or trade order (see Manage documents), and are stored there more as an "audit trail" on what's been generated in the background. Regardless of the folder name you define, reports are stored directly under the contact, portfolio, or trade order. The folder name only affects how the audit trail of generated reports is structured.

title: Publish reports to documents
body: Document name

title: Publish reports to documents
body: You can set a common name for the report file, allowing you to easily name the published reports files consistently, for example as "Monthly report.pdf" or "Q1 Report.pdf". The published report appears with this file name in the documents of each customer, portfolio, or trade order. If you don't define a document name, your reports are saved with the name the report generation assigns them (the name the report file would get when printing it out directly).

title: Publish reports to documents
body: Document tags

title: Publish reports to documents
body: You can add tags to categorize your report files within your documents - the tags you define here will be added to each of the report files. Tagging allows you to find your documents easily, and for example to show them in different sections within FA Front.

title: Publish reports to documents
body: Click Generate report.

title: Publish reports to documents
body: The system saves the generated reports directly to the documents of the contacts, portfolios, or trade orders (for example, as PDFs) instead of downloading the reports to your computer.

title: Delete published reports
body: Publishing reports per contact, portfolio, or trade order generates report files directly to the documents of individual contacts, portfolios, and trade orders. You can't delete the reports directly in the New report window, Generated reports tab. To delete the reports, you need to remove them from each contact, portfolio, or trade order.

title: Delete published reports
body: This can be done by deleting reports one-by-one in the Contact, Portfolio or Trade order window, but you can also mass-delete reports in the Administration view, Documents tab:

title: Delete published reports
body: Search for all the reports that were published so that they are visible in the view (enter a search criterion or select a tag to search with). Use the document name or tags you defined during publishing.

title: Delete published reports
body: Click Delete document. This deletes all reports currently visible.

body: Track your investments through various set limits or models.

title: You can

title: You can

title: You can
body: Take out reports Ex-ante costs and charges and Ex-post costs and charges, based on the expense classification you made.

title: You can

title: Update contact information with Roaring
body: You can get up-to-date contact information from local authorities in Finland and Sweden by using the Roaring integration.

title: Prerequisites
body: You need an agreement with Roaring to use the integration. Roaring can guide you through getting the necessary agreements and permits.

title: Prerequisites
body: The contacts whose information you want to fetch must have their social security numbers stored as the Contact ID in FA Back.

title: Setting up
body: To set up the Roaring connection, see Set up Roaring connection.

title: Running contact information updates
body: To update contact information using the Roaring integration, go to the Contacts view, search for the contacts whose information you want to update, and select Roaring.io → Update from Finnish population register or Roaring.io → Update from Swedish population register at the bottom of the view.

title: Running contact information updates
body: The following fields in the Contact window are updated:

title: Running contact information updates
body: Name

title: Running contact information updates
body: Address

title: Running contact information updates
body: The following fields are updated only from the Swedish population register:

title: Running contact information updates
body: Tag group Deregistration is updated with the official reason code if the contact has been removed from the population register. The reason codes are listed on the Roaring website.

title: Running contact information updates
body: Key figure Death date is updated with the death date of a deceased person. This is accompanied by the Deregistration tag AV.

title: Running contact information updates
body: Key figure Guardian is updated with the social security number of the contact's legal guardian and the date of validity.

title: Related links
body: Communications in FA Back reference

title: Documents
body: You can store documents and links in the FA system by linking them to a contact, portfolio, security, transaction, or trade order. You can then send the documents to your clients via email. FA also allows you to send documents to be signed by your client, and you can monitor the signing process.

title: Manage documents
body: FA allows you to store and link documents related to contacts, portfolios, securities, transactions, and trade orders. You can store documents by uploading them as files or linking them from an external source. This topic describes how you can search and manage documents on the level of individual contacts, portfolios, securities, transactions, or trade orders. To manage all documents in the FA system, see Administering documents in FA Admin guide.

title: Manage documents
body: When uploading documents, the supported file types are: PDF, DOC, DOCX, ODT, XLS, XLSX, PPT, PPTX, ODP, ODS, TXT, CSV, XML, PNG, JPG, RTF, and MP3.

title: Upload documents
body: You can add new documents in the Document tab of the Contact, Portfolio, Security, Transaction, or Trade order window, or in the Documents section of Overview or customer details. You can upload documents as files from your computer or link them from external sources (for linking documents, see Link external documents).

title: Upload documents
body: To add documents, do the following:

title: Upload documents
body: Open the contact, portfolio, security, transaction, or trade order where you want to add documents and go to the Documents tab or section.

title: Upload documents
body: Click Upload file and select the documents from your computer.

title: Upload documents
body: The documents are added to the list. To search the documents, see Search documents.

title: Link external documents
body: You can also add documents as links to external sources such as URL addresses or your internal document library. Linked documents are listed the same way as documents in the system, but they have the icon and the extension ".link".

title: Link external documents
body: To upload a linked document, do the following:

title: Link external documents
body: Open the contact, portfolio, security, transaction, or trade order where you want to add documents and go to the Documents tab or section.

title: Link external documents
body: Click Upload link, and fill in the fields:

title: Link external documents
body: Document name. Name shown in the document list.

title: Link external documents
body: Link to document. URL of the document. The link can point to, for example, a document stored online or in your internal document library.

title: Link external documents
body: Click Save.

title: Link external documents
body: The document is now linked to the system. If you need to edit a link, remove it and add it again. To search the documents, see Search documents.

title: Download documents
body: To download a document, right-click it and select Download document. The document is downloaded to your computer.

title: Modify documents
body: You can modify the name, tags or folder location of a document:

title: Modify documents
body: Right-click the document and select Modify document.

title: Modify documents
body: Modify the document information:

title: Modify documents
body: Rename. Change the document name or folder. You can use this field to move the document into or out of a sub-folder (you can't directly edit the document file path). For example, you can rename a document "Contracts/NewContract.pdf" to place it into a sub-folder called "Contracts". To move the document back into the parent folder from "Contracts", you can rename the document "../NewContract.pdf". You can't delete sub-folders.

title: Modify documents
body: Document tags. Change the document tags.

title: Modify documents
body: Click Save.

title: Modify documents
body: The document information is now modified.

title: Delete documents
body: To delete a document, do the following:

title: Delete documents
body: Right-click the document and select Delete document.

title: Delete documents
body: Click Yes.

title: Delete documents
body: The document is deleted and the list is updated.

title: Search documents
body: You can find uploaded or linked documents in the Documents tab of the corresponding window. You can also search documents in the Documents section of Overview for contacts and portfolios, or by opening a customer in the Customers view. You can search for documents by name, date, time, modifier, and tags.

title: Search documents
body: The documents are listed in a table that shows the document name, the document type as an icon, the date, time, and user who last modified the document, and the document tags. To see documents in sub-folders when searching, tick the checkbox next to the tree structure icon . You can enable this, for example, to see portfolio and transaction documents when viewing a contact. If a document folder has separate sub-folders, you can select them in a drop-down menu.

title: System security measures
body: The following measures prevent users from uploading harmful documents into the system:

title: System security measures
body: Maximum document size. To define the maximum file size users can upload, see Preference - Administration in FA Back reference. For example, if a typical file size is 10 MB, you can reject files larger than 25 MB.

title: System security measures
body: Limit document upload frequency. To control how many documents a user can upload and how frequently (for example, a user can upload 1 new document every 10 seconds), see Preference - Administration in FA Back reference. If the system detects suspiciously frequent document uploads from a single user, the user is prohibited from uploading documents for some time.

title: System security measures
body: Virus scanning. The system can scan all uploaded documents for viruses for additional security. If the system detects a virus, the document upload is prevented. By default, virus scanning is disabled. Contact FA if you want to enable virus scanning.

title: Related links
body: Preference - Administration in FA Back reference

title: Document signing
body: FA document signing allows you to:

title: Document signing
body: Send documents from the FA document bank to be signed by your clients with their BankID (Signicat signing service).

title: Document signing
body: Monitor the signing status of documents.

title: Document signing
body: Cancel document signing requests.

title: Document signing
body: FA provides Signicat services through FA agreements. We charge customers separately for these services.

title: Document signing
body: The following sections describe how you can ask the client for authentication to view the document and administer the document signing functionality.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: Ask for authentication to view a document

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: When you send a document for signing, the system by default requires authentication (for example, BankID) from the signee before they can view the document. You can adjust this setting by doing the following:

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: Go to Tools → Administer → Signicat sign.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: See the Don't require authentication before viewing the document field in the Authentication section.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: To require authentication from the signee, make sure the checkbox is unticked (default).

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: To disable the mandatory authentication, tick the checkbox.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: Click Done.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: Authentication settings are now saved and the system asks the signee to authenticate depending on your selection.

title: Administer document signing functionality
body: Administer document signing functionality

title: Administer document signing functionality
body: Before you can use the document signing functionality, FA needs to order the signing method from Signicat and finalise the configuration of the signing process for you.

title: Related links
body: Manage documents in FA User guide

title: Related links
body: Set up document signing notifications in FA Admin guide

title: Send documents for signing
body: FA allows you to send documents for signing to one or more of your clients. The signees receive a link to the document via email or SMS. When they have signed the document, you can download it in FA Back.

title: Send documents for signing
body: To send a document for signing, do the following:

title: Send documents for signing
body: Make sure the following signee details are defined in the Contact window:

title: Send documents for signing
body: Social security number or national identification number in Basic info tab, External ID field.

title: Send documents for signing
body: Email and Phone fields in Address info tab. The document link is sent to the contact's first email address and to their phone number if defined. The email address and phone number are required if you select to send signing notifications always. If you set signing notifications to "If valid email address/phone number is found", the corresponding field is required. For details on signing notification settings, see Set up document signing notifications in FA Admin guide.

title: Send documents for signing
body: Upload documents in the Contact, Portfolio, Transaction or Trade order window, Documents tab. Add the "Document signing-Waiting" tag.

title: Send documents for signing
body: Go to the Contacts view and select the signee's contact. Click Document signing → Send documents for signing at the bottom of the view.

title: Send documents for signing
body: Check the Validation column of documents you want to send. If a document has errors, you need to correct them before it can be sent. Typically, errors relate to missing signee details (see step 1).

title: Send documents for signing
body: Click Send.

title: Send documents for signing
body: The system produces a notification that shows the number of documents sent and the number of errors. Sent documents are tagged with "Document signing-Pending". Documents with errors are tagged with "Document signing-Error".

title: Send documents for signing
body: The signee receives an email with a link to view and sign the sent documents. When they sign the document, the system saves it in the Documents tab of the window where you uploaded it (Contact, Portfolio, Transaction, or Trade order window). You can then download the signed document.

title: Add multiple signees
body: Add multiple signees

title: Add multiple signees
body: If you need multiple clients to sign the document, you can add signees who are not linked to the portfolio, transaction, or trade order:

title: Add multiple signees
body: Open the Contact window, Document signing tab of the main signee.

title: Add multiple signees
body: Create a list of signees from available contacts using the arrow buttons. The selected signees need to have the same contact details defined as the main signee (see step 1).

title: Add multiple signees
body: Click Save & close.

title: Add multiple signees
body: When you send a document for signing, all signees on the list now receive a link to the document.

title: Schedule document sending
body: You can schedule the system to send documents for signing on a regular basis. When you schedule document sending, the system tries to send all documents tagged with "Document signing-Waiting". If a document has errors, the parent objects of the document (portfolio or contact) are tagged with "Document signing-Error". The document itself is not tagged, so the system sends it after you correct the validation errors. For more information on scheduling, see Scheduling in FA Admin guide.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: FA allows you to track the signing status of documents so that you know, for example, which documents are waiting for their signees and which documents you need to make corrections for. You can use the following methods to open the Document status list window:

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Open Contacts, Portfolios, Transactions, or Trade orders view and select the ones to view documents for → Document signing → Monitor document signing status.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Go to Tools → Monitor → Document signing status.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: The window shows the following information for each document:

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Status

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Current signing status of the document. For the list of statuses and their meanings, see Document signing statuses.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Signers

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Number of signees that have signed the document out of the total number of signees.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Contact

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Contact, portfolio, transaction, or trade order under which the document is stored.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Document

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Name of the document.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Date sent

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Date when the document was sent for signing.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Last modified

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Last date and time the document information was modified.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Validation

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Errors in the document information, for example, missing signee details. The column is empty if no errors are found. The document can only be sent for signing when it has no errors.

title: Document signing statuses
body: The following document signing statuses and corresponding tags are available:

title: Document signing statuses
body: Not sent. The document is waiting to be sent for signing and has the tag "Document signing-Waiting".

title: Document signing statuses
body: Pending. The document is sent and waiting to be signed and has the tag "Document signing-Pending".

title: Document signing statuses
body: Error. The object that contains the document or contact information has errors. The document has the tag "Document signing-Error". Fix the errors and tag the document with "Document signing-Waiting".

title: Document signing statuses
body: Done. The document is signed and has the tag "Document signing-Done". Both the original and signed document are saved in the FA system.

title: Document signing statuses
body: Canceled. The document signing was canceled by the initiator, meaning the one who requested it. The document has the tag "Document signing-Canceled".

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: You can monitor the signing status of documents under a specific contact:

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Open the Contacts view and select the contact to monitor.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Click Document signing → Monitor document signing status to open the signing status window.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Check the Validation column for errors. For documents with errors, you can click on the contact name to open the Overview and edit the missing or incorrect information.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: You can use the same method for portfolios, transactions, and trade orders as well.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: You can also monitor the signing status of documents stored under contacts, portfolios, transactions, and trade orders in one window:

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Go to Tools → Monitor → Document signing status. The window that opens shows a list of all documents with a tag related to the document signing process.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Click the rows highlighted with "Error" to open the Overview. Edit the missing or incorrect information.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: To cancel a signing request, do the following:

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Open the Tasks view.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Filter the task list to find the request to cancel. Signing request task titles follow the pattern: "<datetime> Awaiting signature: <document path>".

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Use the My tasks list to cancel your own signing request.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Use the All tasks list to cancel someone else's signing request.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Open the signing request task and click Cancel signing request.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: The signing request is canceled both on the Signicat side and on the FA side. If you need to send the document for signing again, tag the document with "Document signing-Waiting" and follow the instructions in Send documents for signing.

title: Send documents via email
body: FA allows you to send documents stored under a contact, portfolio, transaction, or trade order to your clients via email.

title: Send documents via email
body: For sending reports, the process is different (see Send reports via email).

title: Send documents via email
body: To send documents via email, do the following:

title: Send documents via email
body: Add the tag "Document sending-Waiting" to the documents you want to send.

title: Send documents via email
body: Go to Tools → Send documents via emails and use the checkboxes on the left side of the window to select which documents to send.

title: Send documents via email
body: Fill in the fields:

title: Send documents via email
body: Source of reporting addresses

title: Send documents via email
body: Source of the recipient email addresses. Select "Contact" to use the email address defined in the Contact window, Address info tab. Select "Portfolio" to use the email address defined in the Portfolio window, Reporting tab. You can see the email addresses fetched the source in the Recipient email address(es) column.

title: Send documents via email
body: Email template

title: Send documents via email
body: Email message template defined in Preference → Reporting → Email. For more information about email templates, see Send and receive emails and SMS messages.

title: Send documents via email
body: Click Send.

title: Send documents via email
body: The documents are sent to the client.

title: Key figures for contacts, portfolios and securities
body: Configurable key figures allow you to define what key figure values you want to store on your contacts, portfolios and securities. Key figures allow you to store a time series of values of your choice. For example, you can store fee percentages that change over time to your portfolios, or your key figure on your instruments, extending the possibilities of storing data into FA.

title: Rebalance window
body: You can create model portfolios or investment plans and use them to keep your investment portfolios in balance. Rebalancing creates trade orders to buy and sell securities according to the model. For general information about rebalancing approaches and for instructions, see Rebalance in FA User guide.

title: Rebalance window
body: The Rebalance window allows you to define the rebalance parameters and the securities to rebalance. The window lists securities in the portfolio or model portfolio/ investment plan linked to the rebalanced portfolio and indicates the shares of these securities in the investment portfolio and model. The portfolio account is also included in rebalancing.

title: Rebalance window
body: At the top of the Rebalance window, you can define the rebalancing parameters.

title: Affected portfolios
body: Affected portfolios

title: Affected portfolios
body: The Affected portfolios section defines which portfolios are rebalanced.

title: Affected portfolios
body: Rebalance against

title: Affected portfolios
body: Target for rebalancing, in order of descending priority. The system uses the first target in the list if defined. Otherwise, the system the target with the next highest priority. The targets can be:

title: Affected portfolios
body: "Model portfolio", "Investment plan" – Model portfolio or investment plan linked to the portfolio.

title: Affected portfolios
body: "Portfolio itself" – Target shares you specify in the Rebalance window.

title: Affected portfolios
body: "Empty portfolio" – An option to empty the portfolio – this will set all the new shares as 0% and sell everything, regardless of the linked model or plan.

title: Affected portfolios
body: Include sub-portfolios

title: Affected portfolios
body: Aggregates positions and investment plan/ model portfolio contents also from the rebalanced portfolio's subportfolios. This allows you to divide holdings into subportfolios and rebalance everything at once through the main portfolio. Trade orders are created either to the main portfolio or the sub-portfolios based on which portfolio or portfolio's investment plan / model portfolio the trade order's security can be found in: for sells of existing positions, trade orders are created in the same portfolio where the position currently is, and for buys, trade orders are created in the same portfolio which has the position in the investment plan / model portfolio.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Rebalance parameters

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The Rebalance parameters section defines rebalancing logic.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Date

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The rebalancing date. This date affects:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The market prices, rebalanced portfolio shares, trade order amounts. The percentage shares of securities in the portfolio are determined based on the market prices on the rebalancing date. The market prices on this date are used to calculate the amount in the suggested trade orders.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The content of the model portfolio/ investment plan. The target shares are fetched based on the selected rebalancing date

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Restrict rebalancing to accounts

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Restrict rebalancing to only reach the target level for portfolio accounts, without any other buys or sells. This feature has different effects depending on the rebalance method (buying with extra cash or using cash from sells) – see Rebalance methods.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: With the conservative rebalancing method, securities are bought and sold only to achieve the target level of the account. If the account has excess cash, the selected securities (largest first) are bought as long as there is available cash but nothing is sold. If the account has a lack of cash, the selected securities (largest first) are sold until the account reaches the target level - nothing is bought and securities are sold only to rebalance the account to the defined level.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: With the exchange method, if the account balance is below the target, it is first rebalanced with sells. After this, the excess cash from sells is used to buy the securities to be rebalanced, but securities are sold only to cover all the necessary buys. If there are Executable sell trade orders, the cash coming in from these is taken into account when selling the securities.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: With full rebalance, if the account balance is below the target, it is first rebalanced with sells. After this, the excess cash from sells is used to buy the securities to be rebalanced, but securities are sold only to cover all the necessary buys.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: You can also define the rebalance settings in Preference ("Define target range for portfolio's cash balance", "Define how much negative cash balance is increased by to cover all negative cash" and "Define how much positive cash balance is decreased by to ensure positive cash balance"). These preferences determine how rebalancing tries to achieve the target level for accounts. See Preference - Portfolios for details.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Rebalance method

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Rebalancing approach: conservative rebalance, full rebalance, full rebalance including outstanding orders, exchange, invest cash, cover for cash, and model change (see Rebalance methods).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Filter out small trade orders based on

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The minimum size for the trade orders that rebalancing should create. The size restrictions don't apply if you sell an entire position away from the portfolio (see Rebalance). Set the minimum difference between the portfolio position and the model as:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Minimum change % (absolute/ percentage points)" - The difference in percentage points.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Minimum change % (relative / percentage change)" - The relative difference in percentage.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Minimum trade amount" - The minimum trade amount in portfolio currency. Alternatively, you can define a Minimum trade amount for each of your securities (see Security window).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Position is within min/max share" - The difference defined with the minimum and maximum thresholds in the model. Trade orders are created only if your position deviates outside of the minimum and maximum thresholds. The minimum trade amount for each trade order is calculated as follows:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: For "buy": ( target share - min share ) * portfolio value

title: Rebalance parameters
body: For "sell": ( max share - target share ) * portfolio value

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Positions that don't have the thresholds specified int the model are rebalanced without filtering when "Position is within min/max share" is selected.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Use cash from accounts

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Accounts to use for buys if you select to buy with extra cash in the portfolio. This option allows you to keep your portfolio fully invested and exclude certain accounts (for example, accrued fee accounts) from rebalancing.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "All accounts" – Use cash on all accounts. You can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Cash accounts" – Use cash on the accounts marked as "cash accounts" in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Cash and credit accounts" – Use cash on cash and credit accounts. You can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Default account only" – Use cash on the portfolio's default account – the first account in the list in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab. If this account is a credit account, you can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Use portfolio credit

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Use credit account for buys. Choose if you want to use the positive account balance and available credit for buys, and if you want to cover the negative balance. The option is shown if you selected "All accounts", "Cash and credit accounts" or "Default account only" in Use cash from accounts.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Don't use portfolio credit" – Use only positive balance on the credit account for buys, without repaying the used credit.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Use portfolio credit" – Use available credit and positive balance on the credit account for buys, without repaying the used credit.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Repay portfolio credit" – Use positive balance on the credit account. In case of negative balance, rebalance the credit account account to 0. The cash is rebalanced to the default portfolio account, and you can then repay the credit manually. If a portfolio has no accounts other than the credit account, the credit is repaid automatically.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Calculate fees to trade orders

title: Rebalance parameters
body: An option to calculate fees, or to estimate the effect of an upcoming fee when generating buy and sell trade orders. If a fee is calculated, the effect of the fee is taken into account when determining how many units you can buy with you available cash and how much money you get from sells. This allows you to estimate the effects of upcoming transaction fees more accurately. Fees are also saved in the Fees field for each trade order.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Don't calculate fees" - Don't calculate fees in trade orders.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Calculate portfolio specific fees" - Calculate a transaction fee defined in the portfolio (Portfolio window, Fees tab).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Calculate fixed fees" - Calculate a fee defined as a percentage in the field available next to the selection.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Use security minimum trade amount

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Option to set the minimum trade amount of the security as the minimum trade order amount. A trade order is only created if the amount is at least equal to the security minimum trade amount. If you also use "Minimum trade amount" for Filter out small trade orders based on, rebalancing first applies the filter and then checks the security minimum trade amount.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The system starts rebalancing from the largest potential trade order and works towards the smallest one. If both settings are enabled, the system does the two checks and if a trade order fails them, the following logic is used:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Filter out the trade order without reallocating the trade order if the minimum trade amount is not reached. If the last security to rebalance fails, the trade order is always filtered out.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Reallocate the trade order amount if the security minimum trade amount is not reached.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Example 1: The rebalancing amount is 550. Minimum trade amount is 100. Security minimum trade amount is 600. The system first checks if 550 > 100 (true), and then checks if 550 > 600 (false). No trade order is created.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Example 2: The rebalancing amount is 550. Minimum trade amount is 100. Security minimum trade amount is 300. The system first checks if 550 > 100 (true), and then checks if 550 > 300 (true). The system creates a trade order.

title: Trade order parameters
body: Trade order parameters

title: Trade order parameters
body: Trade order parameters section includes criteria for defining how trade orders are created

title: Trade order parameters
body: Set accounts to trade orders

title: Trade order parameters
body: An option to define accounts for trade orders (Account field):

title: Trade order parameters
body: "Don't set accounts to trade orders" - Create trade orders with "No account".

title: Trade order parameters
body: "Set the default account to trade orders" - Set the portfolio's default account – the first account in the list in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab.

title: Trade order parameters
body: "Set the currency account (or default account) to trade orders" - Use the account with the same currency as the trade order. If such account doesn't exist, this option uses the default account of the portfolio. If the portfolio doesn't have accounts, then the shared accounts for the portfolio are used in the same order: first using the shared account with the same currency as the trade order, and if not found, then using the shared default account.

title: Trade order parameters
body: Create trade orders with status

title: Trade order parameters
body: The status of trade orders.

title: Trade order parameters
body: Set trade order tags

title: Trade order parameters
body: Tags to add to trade orders. For example, you can use tags to mark trade orders with execution instructions.

title: Trade order parameters
body: Set portfolio tags

title: Trade order parameters
body: Tags to add to portfolios affected by rebalancing. This allows you to for example mark the rebalanced portfolios.

title: Trade order parameters
body: Rebalance memo

title: Trade order parameters
body: Comments and notes on your rebalances, for example, references. Memos are stored in the Rebalance view, which allows you to search for conducted rebalances.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: The bottom of the Rebalance window shows a summary of the positions of the rebalanced portfolio(s). The rebalanced portfolios' positions are grouped per rebalanced portfolio: the icon next to the portfolio ID indicates whether the portfolio is rebalanced against model portfolio, investment plan or portfolio itself, and moving your mouse above a portfolio provides you with more details on how the portfolio is rebalanced, such as the name of the linked model portfolio and the full name of the rebalanced portfolio.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: The content is divided into columns:

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: Security - Position affected by the rebalance (a position in the portfolio or a position in the model).

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: Amount – The current amount (number of units) of the security in the portfolio.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: Purchase value – The current purchase value of the position in the portfolio.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: MPrice – The latest available market unit price of the security, with the date (and time) of the price shown in parentheses.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: Market val. – The total market value of the position in the portfolio with the latest available market price.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: Change - The change between the purchase value and the market value of the position.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: Share % – The current percentage share of the position in the portfolio, calculated with the current market price from the total value of the portfolio.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: Min % and Max % – The minimum and maximum thresholds defined for the position in its investment plan or model portfolio.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: Model % – The share of the security in the model portfolio or investment plan.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: New % – Target share. The field shows the percentage share of the security in the model, if any model is linked to the portfolio. Otherwise, the percentage share of the security in the portfolio is shown. You can edit the value before rebalancing the portfolio and creating trade orders.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: Difference % – The percentage difference between the percentage shares of the security between the portfolio and the model portfolio.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: Difference - The difference between the shares of the security in the portfolio and the model portfolio in portfolio currency.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: You can select portfolios and the positions to include in rebalancing.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
body: When the information for the rebalancing is defined and manually adjusted if necessary, the investment portfolios are rebalanced and trade orders are suggested to be created with the Rebalance button.

title: Trade orders suggested by rebalancing
body: You can view the suggested trade orders after you click Rebalance. You can use filters to search for trade orders within the suggestion.

title: Trade orders suggested by rebalancing
body: Only visible trade orders are saved - to save all suggested trade orders, clear all filters.

title: Trade orders suggested by rebalancing
body: Saving the trade orders is done in the background - you can close the trade order listing and continue using FA while the trade orders are being created. Once the trade order creation is finished in the background, you will see a notification at the bottom-right corner of the view: "Trade orders done. Created trade orders: x.

title: Trade orders suggested by rebalancing
body: You can view the trade orders in the Trade orders view. If a portfolio is rebalanced again, Open trade orders are replaced with new trade orders.

title: File format for importing contacts

title: File format for importing contacts
body: File delimiter. By default, FA is configured to accept semicolon-separated values. You can change it to another character.

title: File format for importing contacts
body: Encoding (UTF-8 or Windows-1252). To import Scandinavian letters, the files should be Windows-1252 encoded to guarantee the correct handling of Scandinavian letters.

title: File format for importing contacts

title: Update contact values
body: You can update existing contacts by importing a new file with corrected data. The system identifies the contact to update by the contact ID, so you need to fill in this field. Note that you must specify if you want to keep the old values in each field.

title: Update contact values
body: To replace the field value, specify the new value in the import file.

title: Update contact values

For multi-value fields, you can import new values while keeping old ones using three stars (***). For example: ***<new value1>,<new value2>.

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Bookkeeping preferences include settings for managing and setting up accounting. The first steps in setting up accounting are to 1) create bookkeeping accounts in the system through the Account set preferences and 2) create appropriate posting rules in the Posting rule preferences.

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Changes in bookkeeping preferences are tracked:

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Changes in account sets and posting rules are recorded in FA audit logs available in the FA Admin Console: FA audit logs.

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Changes in posting rules are recorded in versions of each posting rule: Track data modifications through versions.

title: Account set
body: In the Account set preferences, you can define account sets to be used when defining posting rules. An account set consists of a code, account set name, and individual accounts. Define an account number and name for each account.

title: Account set
body: You can add the accounts manually one by one or click Import/export and then copy and paste the accounts on separate lines as text.

title: Account set
body: You can also fetch the account name and number dynamically from the account information of a portfolio or reported transaction's security:

title: Account set
body: Typing SEC into the account number uses the transaction's security name as the account name and the transaction's security trade code as the account number.

title: Account set
body: Typing ACC into the account number uses the transaction's portfolio's secondary account number as the account code, or if not defined, the currency trade code of the portfolio account as the account code.

title: General
body: In the General preferences, you can define the logic used to create bookkeeping postings from transactions. The following table lists the configurations available:

title: Posting rule
body: Posting rule

title: Posting rule
body: In the Posting rule preferences, you can define different rules that affect the formation of the bookkeeping report or the generation of postings (if bookkeeping is enabled). These rules describe, which transactions, linked to a security with certain characteristics, are recorded to the debit and credit sides of the chosen bookkeeping account.

title: Posting rule
body: A posting rule consists of a name, a code, and a link to a defined account set. The link to an account set defines the accounts available for defining the posting rules: only the accounts defined for the linked account set are available.

title: Posting rule
body: In addition to the basic information, a posting rule consists of multiple precise rules, which are defined against a certain bookkeeping account: the whole posting rule is a combination of several, individual rules, each representing an entry in bookkeeping. A new individual rule to the posting rule is added with the Add button at the bottom of the window.

title: Posting rule
body: When posting-based bookkeeping is enabled, you can see an extended set of selectable rules and charge types compared to the available fields in standard bookkeeping. When bookkeeping is not enabled, you can only see the standard options. In addition, you can search for posting rules by filtering a posting rule set with the content of the available columns.

title: Posting rule
body: An individual rule is defined as a combination of a certain transaction type, security's characteristics, account from the chosen account set, and decision of debit/credit:

title: Posting rule
body: Transaction type*

title: Posting rule
body: Choose the transaction type of the posting rule, e.g. which types of transaction the individual rule is applied to.

title: Posting rule
body: Security

title: Posting rule
body: Choose the characteristics of the securities to apply the rule to. You can choose from:

title: Posting rule
body: Security base type, Security type, Security subtype, or individual Security. You can select only one of these properties.

title: Posting rule
body: Country, Marketplace, Class (1 through 5), or Issuer. You can select one or more of these properties.

title: Posting rule
body: If you have multiple rules, specific rules are applied over more generic ones. The security characteristics are taken into account in bottom-up order. For example, if you have separate rules for security country "Finland" and security type "Stock", the rule based on the security country is applied for your Finnish stocks (the country is below the security type in the list).

title: Posting rule
body: Account*

title: Posting rule
body: Choose the bookkeeping account the entry is recorded to from the account set linked to the posting rule (the accounts are defined in the Account set preferences for the linked account set)

title: Posting rule
body: Value

title: Posting rule
body: Leave empty, or choose from positive or negative. For each individual rule, you can define that the individual rule is executed and a posting is generated only if the value of the rule will be positive or negative. You can thus define that even if other rule criteria are met, only execute the individual rule if the positive/negative value criteria are met.

title: Posting rule
body: Charge type

title: Posting rule
body: Choose the charge type(s) of the rule by choosing them from the check boxes next to the type (the types available are described in the table below). Checking a charge type also allows you to combine different values by adding or subtracting them: when checking multiple types, these values are added up, and the + and - signs above the check boxes determine whether the checked value is taken into the calculation as positive or negative, e.g. added or subtracted in the calculation.

title: Posting rule
body: Posting date

title: Posting rule
body: Choose from Transaction date or Settlement date. Decides whether the posting date of the created posting is set based on the transaction date or settlement date of the transaction the posting is created through.

title: Posting rule
body: Payment*

title: Posting rule
body: Choose from debit or credit. Determines whether the individual rule will be recorded to the debit or credit side.

title: Posting rule
body: A new individual rule is added to the posting rule or the changes made to the rule are saved with the + button, after which the rule is shown in the rule table below the posting rule basic information.

title: Posting rule
body: The individual rules within an entire posting rule are shown in the table, grouped under the rule-defining conditions of transaction type + security's chosen characteristic. If an individual rule is changed, it is then re-grouped if necessary - you can always see an up-to-date grouping of your individual posting rules.

title: Posting rule
body: The posting rule table allows you to see all the individual rules with a quick glance, and the information of the rules is divided into columns.

title: Posting rule
body: Name

title: Posting rule
body: The name represents the name of the posting rule group, e.g. the combination of transaction type and selected security characteristics that define when the individual rules within the group are applied. The group name is shown as "Transaction type name + Security character + Second security character", e.g. "Buy + Stock" or "Sell + Stock + Finland".

title: Posting rule
body: Account

title: Posting rule
body: Shows the selected account of the individual rule

title: Posting rule
body: Posting date

title: Posting rule
body: Shows the selection for the posting date for the individual rule

title: Posting rule
body: Credit/Debit

title: Posting rule
body: Shows the selection for the debit/credit for the individual rule

title: Posting rule
body: Charge type

title: Posting rule
body: Shows all the selected charge types as "Type 1 + Type 2 + Type 3". The list shows which charge types were checked for the individual rule and how, by adding or subtracting, they are calculated together.

title: Posting rule
body: To manage the posting rules more effectively, the following functions are available:

title: Posting rule
body: Duplicating an entire posting rule. To duplicate an entire posting rule set, e.g. all the individual rules defined within a posting rule set, click the Duplicate button on the left below the defined posting rule sets.
